Description: Fragment of gold glass: transparent colourless glass, flat and composed of two layers fused together. Between the two layers, doubtless on the upper surface of the under-sheet, is a conventionalized vine design built up from short, rectangular lengths of gold leaf. Probably the layer with the decorations was reheated until a slightly viscous state was reached so as to make the decorations adhere. Probably the border of a decorative plaque.
Curator's comments: This piece is part of a larger study on gold sandwich glass techniques, currently ongoing. Initial publication: Hidetoshi Namiki and Yasuko Fujii, “A Study of the Cut Gold Leaf Decoration Techniques on Ancient Gold Sandwich Glass, with Emphasis on the Hellenistic ‘Kirikane’ Technique,” in Annales du 20e congrès de l’Association Internationale pour l’Histoire du Verre (AIHV), Fribourg/Romont, 7–11 septembre 2015, ed. Sophie Wolf and Anne de Pury-Gysel (Rahden: Verlag Marie Leidorf, 2017): 68–72.

Bibliography: H. Coutts, 'Gold of the Pharaohs' (Edinburgh 1988), p. 96 [88]; C. Favard-Meeks in P. Brissaud & C. Zivie-Coche (eds), 'Tanis : travaux récents sur le tell Sân el-Hagar : Mission française des fouilles de Tanis, 1987-1997' (1998), p. 114; W. M. F. Petrie 'et al.', 'Tanis' I (1885), 34, right column.
